Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story:
My phone buzzed at 2 a.m., jolting me awake. It was Sam, my closest friend, sobbing on the other end. “I just found out my dad’s in the hospital,” he choked out. My heart twisted. I knew what he needed—someone to listen, to stay on the line, to help him breathe through the panic. I wanted nothing more than to be that person for him, to give him my full attention and comfort.

But as I tried to focus on his words, another notification popped up on my work phone. A package I was supposed to deliver had just arrived at the depot, later than expected but still within the day. My boss’s message was clear: “Deliver ASAP. Customer is waiting.” I was the only one on the night shift. If I didn’t go now, the customer would complain, and I’d risk my job.

I stared at the ceiling, phone pressed to my ear, torn between being the friend Sam desperately needed and the reliable delivery person my job demanded. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
